title: 107_s2940
content: The Act titled "Coast Guard Readiness Act of 2002" and Section 2 discusses Interagency Homeland Security Fusion Centers. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to establish Interagency Homeland Security Fusion Centers to coordinate maritime homeland security information, facilitate information sharing among Federal agencies and foreign governments, and provide intelligence on maritime threats to the United States. Members of the Centers will be designated from various Federal agencies and foreign governments. Interagency Fusion Centers, comprised of personnel from various Federal agencies and foreign governments, will have access to databases and information systems to coordinate maritime homeland security efforts. The Center, with federal agency members, ensures database security, analyzes information to identify threats, and alerts government agencies promptly. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit an implementation plan within a year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a detailed plan to implement Interagency Homeland Security Fusion Centers, including the number and location of the centers, policies for establishing and operating them, coordination with other intelligence centers, and proposed legislation for agency authorities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a detailed plan for Interagency Homeland Security Fusion Centers, including the Federal agencies necessary for membership. SEC. 3. COAST GUARD FUNDING FLOORS. The text outlines that budget requests for fiscal years 2004 and 2005 cannot reduce Coast Guard spending below levels allocated in fiscal years 2002 or 2003 for non-homeland security missions, which include marine safety, search and rescue, aids to navigation, living marine resources, marine environmental protection, and ice operations. The President has the authority to waive these requirements. The President may waive Coast Guard spending requirements for specific major accidents, national crises, threats to homeland security, or unanticipated events within Coast Guard mission areas. Each waiver recommendation must include a detailed justification. The President may waive Coast Guard spending requirements for major accidents, crises, threats to homeland security, or unanticipated events within Coast Guard mission areas. Recommendations for waivers must include specific information and reasons why the Coast Guard couldn't respond effectively without the waiver. Intelligence certification is required for waivers based on countering specific, unanticipated threats to homeland security. The Intelligence Community is taking decisive steps to reduce the probability of unanticipated threats in the future. SEC. 4. REPORT ON ACCELERATING THE INTEGRATED DEEPWATER SYSTEM. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Coast Guard Commandant, must submit a report within 90 days of the National Homeland Security and Combating Terrorism Act of 2002 enactment. The report will analyze the feasibility of speeding up the Coast Guard's Integrated Deepwater System procurement from 20 years to 10 years, estimate additional resources needed, and detail the enhanced capabilities and operational efficiencies resulting from accelerated procurement. The report will analyze the feasibility of speeding up the Coast Guard's Integrated Deepwater System procurement from 20 years to 10 years, estimate additional resources needed, and detail the enhanced capabilities and operational efficiencies resulting from accelerated procurement. It also provides a revised asset phase-in schedule consistent with the accelerated rate of procurement.
